Admiral Alvin Holsey confirmed his retirement date as December 12, 2025, marking the end of his service.

keyTakeAways: Admiral Alvin Holsey, the commander of U.S. Southern Command, is retiring at the end of 2025, one year after being sworn in in November 2024.
The Pentagon denies that Holsey expressed reservations about the legality of U.S. drug interdiction operations in the Caribbean.
Tensions between Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Holsey centered on disagreements over the pace and transparency of operations targeting drug cartels in the Caribbean.
The U.S. conducted its fifth known strike on a drug-trafficking boat off Venezuela’s coast in early October 2025, killing six people.
President Donald Trump reportedly authorized the CIA to operate inside Venezuela to curb drug and migrant flows.
U.S. B-52 bombers flew off the coast of Venezuela for over four hours, indicating a significant escalation in military presence.
Holsey served 37 years in the U.S. Navy, including key roles such as commander of Carrier Strike Group One and Military Deputy Commander at Southern Command.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has replaced multiple senior military officials since taking office, signaling a broader restructuring of the military leadership.
Southern Command has faced internal conflict between operational urgency and legal concerns regarding drug trafficking operations in the Caribbean.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Admiral Alvin Holsey, who assumed command of U.S. Southern Command in November 2024, is retiring at the end of 2025, one year into his tenure. His departure follows weeks of tension with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the pace and legality of U.S. military operations targeting drug cartels in the Caribbean, including strikes off Venezuela’s coast. The U.S. recently conducted a fifth known drug interdiction strike, killing six people, and President Donald Trump reportedly authorized CIA operations inside Venezuela to curb drug and migrant flows. Holsey, a 37-year Navy veteran with prior command roles, expressed gratitude for his service and the team's contributions. The Pentagon denies Holsey’s claims of operational concerns, and his resignation was delayed and only formally announced after a meeting at the Pentagon on October 6. This reflects broader military restructuring under Hegseth, who has removed several senior officers, highlighting a period of increased military activity and internal friction over legal and strategic boundaries in the region.
title: Commander Overseeing U.S. Forces in the Caribbean to Retire One Year into Tenure
